awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P/Collaborative Research: Designing a Market-based Optimization Tool for the Future of Work: Balancing Remote Work and Community Vitality in Post-COVID American Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
Remote work practices, which have been greatly accelerated due to the COVID-19 pandemic, will likely play an increased role in post-pandemic work and life for many businesses and their employees. While there are benefits to remote work for some, if remote work persists to a significant degree, it may lead to “hollow towns” wherein city centers experience a serious decline in the absence of office workers. This trend is placing American cities in peril and threatening the livelihoods of many lower-income service workers who depend on people’s coming to the city core to work, shop, and conduct business. This phenomenon is in stark contrast to the pre-pandemic era when cities served as hubs of innovation and economic activities, but also suffered from negative externalities such as traffic congestion and vehicular emissions. This project will build capacity toward designing more desirable future of work scenarios where workplace decisions by skilled workers, i.e., those who can work remotely, can be coordinated across firms in such a manner that the vibrancy of the city as an economic catalyst and an innovation hub is maintained; local businesses and service workers thrive; and traffic congestion is reduced. If successful, this  Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) Planning Grant project will advance the national well-being by helping to retain inner-city service jobs, generate opportunities to re-train service workers, and help maintain American cities' long-standing reputation as economically vibrant clusters of innovation, while mitigating the negative externalities that have plagued city centers for decades.

The project has three thrusts: 1) conduct preliminary analyses to quantify the impacts of increasing levels of remote work on local economy and inner-city service workers; 2) perform exploratory work to understand firms’ responses to alternative policy options that cities may implement to optimize worker presence; and 3) engage stakeholders to assess policy feasibility and their attitudes towards and trust in using technologies to optimize worker presence in offices. The project will focus on Seattle and Phoenix, two cities with very different spatial distributions of economic activities. A novel hierarchical Stackelberg game framework will be developed by leveraging knowledge from behavioral economics, as well as methods in neural networks and evolutionary programming, to model firm behavior in a realistic but uncertain environment. Critical thresholds at which city centers may hollow out and potential early warning signals will be investigated. The project will lay the groundwork in generating new methods and knowledge at the intersection of operations research, economics, public policy, and transportation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented changes to how we live, work, and travel, presenting both challenges and opportunities for society. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation, sought to understand the long-term effects of these disruptions on activity-travel behavior, transportation systems, and urban planning. The research focused on examining shifts in telecommuting, travel mode choices, online shopping habits, and time-use patterns, as well as their implications for equity, well-being, and sustainability. The overarching goal was to understand how changes in people’s activities and travel patterns in the wake of the pandemic might affect the recovery and vibrancy of city centers in the years ahead. 

The findings revealed a significant rise in telecommuting, with many workers continuing to work remotely at least part-time post-pandemic. This shift has profound implications for transportation demand, urban land use, and environmental sustainability. Additionally, the pandemic-induced changes in travel patterns showed a decline in public transit use and an increase in personal vehicle reliance and active transportation modes like walking and cycling. These trends underscore the importance of designing more adaptable and resilient transportation systems. Analysis of time-use patterns highlighted that reduced commuting provided individuals with more discretionary time, contributing to better work-life balance, while the inability to engage in social and recreational activities during the pandemic diminished overall well-being. The research also revealed significant disparities in access to telecommuting opportunities and transportation, driven by factors such as income, education, and job type. These findings highlight the pressing need for inclusive policies to bridge these gaps and ensure equitable access to resources.

The project made a tangible impact on society through the development of a publicly accessible dashboard that allows transportation planners, policymakers, and city officials to monitor behavioral trends and make data-driven decisions. This tool supports the design of equitable, sustainable, and adaptive urban systems based on trends in travel, activity-engagement, and mode choices. The research also informs public policy, guiding efforts to address telecommuting practices, transit recovery, and urban land use planning. Recommendations for hybrid work policies and targeted investments in broadband and transit infrastructure contribute to building more resilient communities. Furthermore, the findings offer a pathway to create environmentally sustainable cities by documenting reduced vehicle miles traveled and the potential for lowering greenhouse gas emissions. Educationally, the project has influenced teaching in transportation and urban planning disciplines by incorporating real-world case studies and data into curricula to train future leaders.

The project’s findings and results offer insights for the future of city centers, highlighting both challenges and opportunities for ensuring their continued vibrancy. The rise of telecommuting and hybrid work models has diminished the need for daily commutes to central business districts, leading to reduced foot traffic and a potential decline in economic activity for businesses reliant on traditional commuting patterns. However, these shifts also present an opportunity to reimagine city centers as more diverse, inclusive, and vibrant spaces. The research suggests that city centers can thrive by pivoting from primarily work-focused environments to multi-functional hubs that integrate residential, cultural, recreational, and retail uses. Strategies for ensuring their vibrancy include fostering mixed-use developments that attract a broader range of activities, investing in public spaces and amenities to enhance their appeal as destinations, and encouraging flexible zoning policies that accommodate emerging trends. The findings also recommend improving access to city centers through sustainable and active transportation options, such as biking, walking, and enhanced public transit. Additionally, addressing disparities in access to digital infrastructure and mobility options ensures that city centers remain equitable and inclusive. These approaches aim to redefine city centers not just as places of work but as dynamic and engaging spaces that attract people for a variety of purposes, ensuring their resilience and relevance in a post-pandemic world.

Overall, this project has advanced our understanding of how major disruptions influence human behavior and urban systems. It has informed strategies for adapting transportation and urban planning to meet emerging societal needs while promoting equity, well-being, and sustainability. By bridging the gap between research and practice, the findings ensure a lasting impact on how we plan and build resilient, inclusive, and thriving communities for the future.
